maml:description.maml:para: Tests an xml schema against an xml file
Tests whether an XML file conforms to its schema.
Name incl. path to the xml file.
Name incl. path to the xsd schema file.
Name incl. path to the xsd schema file.
Name incl. path to the xml file.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1:Tests if the xml file is valid against the specified schema
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> if (Test-XmlSchema -xmlFile 'C:\temp\article.xml' -schemaFile 'C:\temp\article.xsd' ) { Write-Host 'XML file is valid' } else { 'XML file is not valid' }

dev:remarks.maml:para: This can be used to test whether the XML file corresponds to the specified schema.

maml:description.maml:para: Decrypts a text using a key

The function is passed an encrypted text via the `protectedText` parameter. This was previously encrypted with `Protect-String`. The `key` parameter must be either 32 or 16 characters long. Intermediate sizes are padded, but reduce security. If a key longer than 32 characters is passed, an exception is thrown. The counterpart to this function is `protect-string`.
The key must be identical for encryption and decryption.
The encrypted text to be decrypted.
The key that is used for encryption. It should contain either 16 or 32 characters. An exception is thrown for larger values.
The key that is used for encryption. It should contain either 16 or 32 characters. An exception is thrown for larger values.
The encrypted text to be decrypted.

command:example.maml:title: -------------- Example 1:Entschlüsseln des Textes --------------
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\> [string]$protected= '76492d1116743f0423413b16050a5345MgB8AC8ATABrAGwAQgA3AFAARABOAEYAQwArAEIATABwAGEAagBGAFUAQQBUAHcAPQA9AHwAMAAyADEAZABhAGQAMQA1ADQAZgBiADQAZABiADMAOQA4AGMANQA1ADIANQA4ADIANgAyAGMAYgBmAGUANQBjAGEAMgAxADMAMAA3ADQAZQAyAGMAYQA0ADAAMgBjAGYAZQA3ADMAMgAyADgANQAwADcANwA3ADQANABmADEANgA=' PS C:\> [string]$plain= Unprotect-String -protectedText $protected -key 'x&=Ogbu7$43lkn4i'
# Output
I am unsecure

dev:remarks.maml:para: The encrypted text is passed to the function with the original key and decrypted. The result is then `I am unsecure`, i.e. the value originally passed with `Protect-String`.

maml:description.maml:para: Sends a refresh message to the windows desktop

The Update-Desktop function operates as if you were pressing the F5 key on your Windows desktop. It refreshes the icons and their labels on the desktop. This function is used implicitly by the Hide-Extensions and Show-Extensions functions.

command:example.maml:title: --------------- Example 1:Refreshes the desktop ---------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: Refreshes the desktop.

maml:description.maml:para: Performs any function in the context of another culture
This function can be used to format dates or numbers in the context of a different culture. For example, the output of the date in French format.
Specification of the culture in .NET format. `de-DE` for German, `en-US` for English US-American etc.
The script must always be specified in curly brackets.
Specification of the culture in .NET format. `de-DE` for German, `en-US` for English US-American etc.
The script must always be specified in curly brackets.

command:example.maml:title: --------------- Example 1:Date output in french ---------------

dev:remarks.maml:para: The date output is in a culture different from Windows. This makes it easy to provide data exports for another country or to read them.

maml:description.maml:para: Writes a EULANDA metablock via XmlWriter
The function writes a EULANDA specific meta data block into a xml writer object. This function is called implicitly by `Convert-DataToXml` among others.
An instance of the object System.XML.XmlWriter

By setting the parameter `strCase` you can influence the output. If the parameter is omitted or set to `none`, no further conversion is performed. With `lower` the output is converted to lowercase, with `upper` to uppercase and with `capitalize` the first letter of a word is output in uppercase.

By setting the parameter `strCase` you can influence the output. If the parameter is omitted or set to `none`, no further conversion is performed. With `lower` the output is converted to lowercase, with `upper` to uppercase and with `capitalize` the first letter of a word is output in uppercase.
An instance of the object System.XML.XmlWriter

command:example.maml:title: ---- Example 1:Writes metadata using the xml writer object ----
command:example.dev:code:
$encoding = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8 $settings = New-Object System.Xml.XmlWriterSettings $settings.Indent = $true $settings.IndentChars = " " $settings.Encoding = $encoding $stream = New-Object System.IO.MemoryStream $writer = [System.XML.XmlWriter]::Create($stream, $settings)
# Start with the root node $writer.WriteStartDocument() $writer.WriteStartElement('EULANDA') $writer = Write-XmlMetadata -writer $writer -strCase 'upper' ...
<EULANDA> <METADATA> <VERSION>1.22</VERSION>/VERSION> <GENERATOR>EulandaConnect</GENERATOR> <DATEFORMAT>ISO8601</DATEFORMAT> <FLOATFORMAT>US</FLOATFORMAT> <COUNTRYFORMAT>ISO2</COUNTRYFORMAT> <FIELDNAMES>NATIVE</FIELDNAMES> <DATE>2023-02-16T13:05:12</DATE> <PCNAME>PC4ALL</PCNAME> <USERNAME>DOE</USERNAME> </METADATA> </EULANDA>

dev:remarks.maml:para: The metadata is written in conjunction with the xml writer object.
